abstract.p: Norman Venetsky letter on June 13 article warns of difficulty of assessing efficacy of any new stroke treatment technique

block.p: Re ''Stroke Survivors Celebrate Success of Restraint Therapy'' (June 13): We must be very careful in assessing the efficacy of any new treatment technique, particularly those addressing neurological disorders, because distinguishing between normal and abnormal motor function can sometimes be exceedingly difficult. Furthermore, the collective desire of all the parties involved to see improvement can create the illusion of incipient normal movement.

Re ''Stroke Survivors Celebrate Success of Restraint Therapy'' (June 13): We must be very careful in assessing the efficacy of any new treatment technique, particularly those addressing neurological disorders, because distinguishing between normal and abnormal motor function can sometimes be exceedingly difficult. Furthermore, the collective desire of all the parties involved to see improvement can create the illusion of incipient normal movement.

While dramatic improvements are sometimes seen in orthopedic cases, recovery from neurological injuries usually takes months or years. As a longtime physical therapist, I know there are no easy answers to stroke rehabilitation.
